---
title: Work-related rumination declines with age but is moderated by gender
type: pub
encoding: UTF-8

---
<h1>Publikasjon</h1>
<article id="csl-bib-container-BE5C7ZS5" class="csl-bib-container">
  <div class="csl-bib-body"> <div class="csl-entry">Cropley, M., Rydstedt, L. W., Chelidoni, O., Ollis, L., &#38; Querstret, D. (2023). Work-related rumination declines with age but is moderated by gender. <i>Work</i>, <i>76</i>(2), 587–594. <a href="https://doi.org/10.3233/wor-220288">https://doi.org/10.3233/wor-220288</a></div> </div>

</article>
<div id="csl-bib-meta-BE5C7ZS5" class="csl-bib-meta">
  <article id="about-article-BE5C7ZS5" class="about_pub-article">
    <h1>Om</h1>
    Cropley et al. gjennomførte ein studie for å forstå korleis alder og kjønn påverkar måten arbeidstakarar mentalt kviler frå jobben. Dei såg på to typar arbeidsrelatert grubling: affektiv grubling (grubling over arbeidsrelaterte kjensler) og problemløysande fundering (tenking om arbeidsrelaterte problem). Ved å bruke data frå 3,991 fulltidsansatte, fann dei at eldre arbeidstakarar (46 år og eldre) har ein tendens til å gruble mindre om arbeid, men denne nedgangen er påverka av kjønn. Menn rapporterte generelt lågare nivå av arbeidsrelatert grubling på tvers av alle aldrar, med den største kjønnsforskjellen sett i aldersgruppa 56-65 år. Desse funna tyder på at eldre arbeidstakarar kan trenge spesifikke strategiar for å hjelpe dei med å mentalt restituere frå arbeid, og understrekar viktigheita av skreddersydde intervensjonar for ulike aldersgrupper og kjønn.
  </article>
  <article id="keywords-article-BE5C7ZS5" class="keywords-article">
    <h1>Emneord</h1>
    Arbeidsrelatert grubling, Affektiv grubling, Problemløysande fundering, Alder, Kjønn, Mental restitusjon
  </article>
  <article id="abstract-article-BE5C7ZS5" class="abstract-article">
    <h1>Samandrag</h1>
    BACKGROUND: Much is known about the physical effects of work and health, but less is known about how older workers unwind mentally from work, and their post-work ruminative thinking. OBJECTIVE: The present study aimed to explore the association between age, gender and two types of work-related rumination: affective rumination, and problem-solving pondering. METHODS: This study utilized a sample of 3991 full-time employees (working 30 or more hours per week), who were stratified into five age bands (18–25, 26–35, 36–45, 46–55, and 56–65 yrs.). RESULTS: Affective rumination was found to significantly decline in the older age groups (46 + yrs.), but this finding was moderated by gender. Males reported lower work-related rumination over the entire age range, but the greatest difference between males and females was observed in the 56–65 age category. The results for problem-solving pondering mirrored those of affective rumination but with the only exception that there was no significant difference in gender between those aged 18–25 years. CONCLUSION: These findings add to our understanding about how workers (between different age groups) mentally switch off from work and highlight the need for interventions to help older workers mentally recover from the effects of work.
  </article>
